Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate the ethics and values of the computer scientists, information scientists, and software engineers who create algorithms. The research will contribute to the study of ethics and values in science and engineering in four key ways. First, it will bridge silos between philosophical and social scientific approaches to ethics to develop an integrated theoretical approach which simultaneously identifies the analytical, moral reasoning that is happening during the conceptualization and design phase as well as critically analyzes the interplay between an individual's personal ethics and values and the ethics and values created by aspects of policies, institutional, economic, and cultural contexts. Second, the work will further the literature on information ethics by taking an upstream approach that focuses on the design process. The literature concerned with the ethical use of information technology and computer science often focuses on the outcomes of these endeavors; switching the analytical lens, the PI will join a small but growing literature that addresses ethical questions at the design stage. Third, the research will provide an empirical contribution to information science given its investigation of the intersection of people, technology design and knowledge. Finally, by focusing on algorithms, the project will contribute to broader discussions about ethics, values, and big data; algorithms are the driving technique behind the creation of big data sets, yet there is little talk about the decisions and values that shape algorithm design and thus impact big data content.

Broader Impacts: The interrelationship between algorithms and big data is a timely and important topic for investigation. This research will open the black box of algorithmic design in order to provide more transparency for public discussion and debate on the implications of this new way of organizing knowledge and social life. Project outcomes will include a series of provocative images, concepts, and scenarios (to be presented in a well-designed series of cards), to impact graduate students in computer science, information science, and engineering. The PI plans to work with professional organizations such as the Association of Computing Machinery [ACM] and Computer Professionals for Social Responsibility [CPSR] to address a wider range of issues in the professional code of ethics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ethics of Algorithms is a research and educational project that investigates the values and contexts that impact computer scientists, data scientists, and engineers' work with big data and algorithms. To study this topic, the research team conducted fieldwork at three sites and conducted in-depth interviews with the computer scientists and engineers affiliated with each site. The research team used NVivo to analyze the interview and field notes data. Through analysis of this data, the PIs found that computer scientists and engineers had to balance the desire for fast, flexible, and efficient code with concerns about data validity, privacy, and getting products to market. The project demonstrates how issues of validity, security, and privacy arise in big data work and offers suggestions for how computer scientists and engineers can address them in graduate education training.

As part of the educational component of the project, the research team created and tested six ethics scenarios related to big data and working with algorithms at five different universities. Drawing on 59 written evaluations, feedback from instructors, and the experience of using the scenarios in classes, each scenario was revised for optimal use in classrooms. The scenarios are:

An Algorithm Discriminates
Choosing Between Detection, Speed and Accuracy
Data Validity as an Ethical Issue
Sensitive Health Data and Privacy
Taking a Product to Market
Using Sensitive Data Purposefully

Each scenario can be used in computer science, data science, and engineering classes to help students identify and discuss ethical dilemmas that may arise when working with algorithms and big data. All six scenarios are posted at www.ethicsofalgorithms.com. The scenarios are freely available for use.

The PIs trained five graduate students in social science research methods and data analysis as part of this project. The research team has presented findings at research conferences and at universities and colleges, and has manuscripts under review at peer reviewed journals.

Addendum # 1

The National Academy of Engineering reviewed the scenarios described above and posted four of them on the Online Ethics Center (OEC) website. The following scenarios--Using Sensitive Data Purposefully; Taking a Product to Market; Sensitive Health Data and Privacy, and An Algorithm Discriminates--are available on the OEC. The OEC editorial board chose Taking a Product to Market as a featured resource, highlighting it in the Computer, Math, and Physical Sciences section. The OEC is a repository of resources on the ethics of science, engineering, and research that help engineers, scientists, scholars, educators, students, and interested citizens understand and address ethically significant topics and problems that arise in the practice and results of science and engineering. The OEC is located at: http://www.onlineethics.org/
